{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-22393].
  {panel}

We are using Delegated LDAP Authentication in 3.5. In Confluence prior to version 3.5, the administrator could assign LDAP users to Confluence groups and then allow them to log in.

In version 3.5 and higher:
# LDAP users must login first (so that a Confluence user is created)
# Be auto assigned to the confluence-users group
# Then contact the administrator
# Then the Administrator updates the user / group details
# Then the admin contacts the user to let them know that they now have access to the additional space / group.

This process is too slow and cumbersome.

The Administrator should be able to view all users in the LDAP directory, create them as Confluence users and fully set up their access rights / groups.
fields.summary: Confluence Administrator should be able to create new Confluence users from LDAP

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-22392].
  {panel}

We use LDAP for all of our user authentication (Delegated LDAP Authentication).

When using the {{\[~username\]}} notation in 3.5 and higher, the user name and details are only correctly displayed if the username is a registered user in Confluence. Confluence does not automatically search for the user in LDAP as it did in previous versions.

This is a problem for us as many pages refer to people who have never logged into Confluence and are only defined in LDAP (we have < 100 Confluence users and over 250,000 users in LDAP).

The macro behind {{\[~username\]}} should check against all of the user directories when attempting to resolve the username.
fields.summary: support [~username] notation in LDAP only users

  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-22388].

It is possible to see which user exists on Confluence or not from within "Forgot Password" link.

This is bad for security reasons.

If you enter a non-existant username, it currently warns "No user with that username exists". 

Instead, the feature should give same message, regardless of whether the username given actually exists or not, such as "Please check the email address you signed up with".

We appreciate your consideration.

Regards,
JP Support

Confluence administrators (globally) and spaces administrators (for their spaces) should be able to add or remove a space watch on behalf of another user. This is key in teams where new people come onboard and the team leader wants them to keep up to date with what's going on without waiting for them to learn about how notifications work in Confluence.

Within the UI, this can be done in "Manage Watchers" by adding this feature to the "Watching this space" as is exists for "Watching this page" (instead of "You cannot modify this list").

It needs to be added to the API as well, as watchSpace will only work for the authenticated user.

N.B. this is NOT a duplicate of CONF-5866 as there is still no way to add or remove a space watch for another user.

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-22296].
  {panel}

It would be good if there is an option for an admin to select which user directory the new user should be added into on [adding new user|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Managing+Multiple+Directories].

h5. Possible scenarios
* Adding a new user to INTERNAL (or any non-first) directory is not possible if DELEGATING directory is the first in user directories list.
* Adding a new user to multiple user directories is not possible. Perhaps an admin wanted to have few users added to DELEGATING and INTERNAL directory. Reason could be that when LDAP is down/inaccessible, these users still can login using their INTERNAL passwords.

h5. Workaround
Confluence Admin can swap the order of User Directories since currently in Confluence, the new user will get created in the first directory with write access rights listed in User Directories.

h5. Further finding
JIRA has done this well, see JRA-23933. In JIRA, a dropdown option now will appear once there is an INTERNAL and at least one DELEGATING directory:
!JIRA433_AddUser.png!
fields.summary: Provide an option to select user directory on adding/deleting users

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-22272].
  {panel}

h4. The problem

Often, when creating a new page about a topic, related pages exist but the author has not thought of looking up (or has not found) related pages and blogposts before starting to write a new page. This has several negative consequences for the wiki content as a whole:
* Existing content is not utilized to save time when writing new pages
* New documentation does not take into account existing documentation
* Lessons are not being learned about projects and processes as much as could be
* Duplicate or conflicting information enters the wiki, which makes searching slower and more difficult
* Old, inaccurate content may cause loss of productivity or even damage business when obsolete processes and instructions are followed
* The volume of content grows faster than it has to and makes managing both the content and the system more time-consuming and resource-intensive

On a related note, sometimes blog posts inadvertently become pages when people make a "hot topic" news item but don't know that a page exists for it or forget to link to it. The blog post is updated 100 times with attachments, comments, tables and so on until it becomes one of the most viewed "pages" of the wiki. And it can't be moved. Or converted. Or made a part of the page hierarchy in any way.

It is difficult to alleviate this problem by simply "educating staff" when time and money is short, new employees keep entering the user base, and people generally have too little time to do proper research before creating a new page.

h4. The solution

When creating a new page, it would be useful to see which pages already exist that relate to the current page somehow. If other pages already exists that describe the topic, the user could review them. Perhaps a new page does not have to created in the first place but existing documentation can be updated instead. Or perhaps parts of the new page don't have to be written at all because they have already been described elsewhere and the user can instead link to existing documentation.

h4. The benefits

The central benefit here is that users become *aware* of existing, related content and can take it into account better when creating new content. This has several positive implications for the usability and manageability of the system as a whole:
* The overall usability of the wiki soars thanks to better linking, fewer pages, and less conflicting information.
* Management becomes much easier in the long run because there is less content to manage.
* Wikignomes (like me) save hundreds of hours annually in time when they don't have to constantly merge pages, archive pages, link pages, move comments, convert blogs to pages, remind authors to check existing documentation before they create content...

h4. How it works

I'm thinking of a robot much like Hercules, the Atlassian support robot that looks through log files and suggests existing Jira issues based on the error messages found.

The way it would work in my view is that after entering the title for a page and moving the focus away from the title field, Confluence would search for pages that are *similarly named or labeled* and show related pages in a sidebar on the right. The suggestions would have two purposes:
# "Similarly named pages exist. Did you mean to edit one of these pages?"
# "These pages seem to relate to the page you are currently writing. Consider linking to one or several of these pages if they are relevant to the page you are writing."

While I'm at it, this same feature would be awesome in JIRA. :)
fields.summary: Confluence should suggest existing content when creating a new page or blogpost

  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-22270].
  {panel}

Currently, if a test run triggers faults in background tasks and those tasks aren't being directly tested, we won't know unless someone skims the test log. Similarly, if there's a spontaneous breakage in the background tasks in performance test run, we'll never know. To address this, we should:
# Add failure tracking in all quartz tasks, worker threads, and any other thread that gets created that aren't servlet threads,
# Add a way to turn these failures into test failures. This could be a post acceptance test target (eg 100_check_workers) to query confluence for any failures and fail the build if it detects some, or it could be a test-specific handler that turns any unexpected failure into a johnson event.
# Add functestrpc hooks for pausing and resuming failure tracking in these threads, to allow us to avoid spurious failures. We could make the hooks specific to each kind of worker we create, so turning off indexing errors won't turn off email notification errors, etc.
# Add calls in tests that directly cause failures in these background tasks to suspend tracking while they break things, so that we don't mix up their (expected) failures with real problems.

So we can commit this change early and figure out if this could give us usable results, consider adding a temporary build profile that alone runs the new verifier.
fields.summary: Add background task monitoring to tests

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-22240].
  {panel}

When using either the deprecated media tag \!movie.mov! or the new multimedia macro, resizing a quicktime movie attachment does not actually change the size of the movie - just the size of the viewport.

This appears to be due to the missing 'scale' attribute from the object/embed tags generated. So the object viewport changes but the movie is still the original size, resulting in a cropped media file.

Reproduce:

# Create a movie of size 1600x900 px
# attach to page
# edit page and add multimedia macro
# add width of 800 and height of 450

The movie will be displayed and checking the source will show both the object and embed tags have width & height set as per the macro settings, however a 'cropped' version of the movie is shown. 

In order to 'fix', use "Inspect Element" and add the attribute scale="aspect" to the object and embed tags and this will fix the display and present the movie correctly. However, the fix is not permanent of course... it just proves what needs to be done in the source code to get things to work as expected.
fields.summary: Quicktime .mov attachments are cropped rather than scaled to specified size

When you delegate User Management in Confluence 3.5 + (embedded crowd) to Jira 4.3+, JIRA will return a 403 Forbidden error if the IP Confluence makes the user management request from is not included in a whitelist.

Confluence does not handle this error gracefully- It prints the raw html returned from the 403 error as opposed to a useful message to the Administrator.

It ought to include possible reasons for why this might have failed, as the headers returned, and the IP the request originated from.

Alternatively, JIRA could return more useful feed back in the 403 message body, and Confluence can craft a better error based on the 403 body.

Hi Atlassian,

We currently are looking into a bug with our Theme Builder plugin that relates to the Drag'n'Drop feature within confluence to attach files to the page.

It appears to be a specific element may be required in the theme mark-up that needs to be added in order for the drag and drop feature to work correctly. h3.Problem
How it happens:
# On a page with the wiki markup attached, clicking in the Edit icon.
# clock starts spinning, and after a while it gets the attached "script error". 
# If you click *Continue*, the loop starts over again and I eventually get the same error message.
# If you click *Stop script*, I may edit but the page content is now empty.

h3. Addiction information
# Running this mySQL queries with the following pattern:
{code} select b.BODY from BODYCONTENT b where b.CONTENTID = XXXXXXXX; {code}
## the output of which is directed in the two text files attached:
### {{body-NOTOK.txt}} contains the page content which DOES cause the problem
### {{body-OK.txt}} contains the page content which does NOT cause the problem
## then was translated those two text files into hexadecimal format:
{code}
od -xc body-NOTOK.txt > body-NOTOK.hex
od -xc body-OK.txt > body-OK.hex
{code}
## Comparing both, you will notice that some SPACE characters (ASCII hex'20') in the 'OK' file, have been turned into hex'a0' in the NOTOK file, and that those seem to be the *only differences* between them.

h3.Fix

There is none yet.

h3.Workaround
Use IE.

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-22039].
  {panel}

If you copy a nested bullet list from any of the mozilla products, you get a garbled nested list (please refer to the attached screenshot).  

Turns out this is because of a bug in Mozilla's rendering engine and then Confluence takes it a step further and garbles that beyond recognition. I run into this frequently when pasting info from email into our Wiki.

Below is described a workaround.  My ask is that confluence implement the ability to fix the html.  Since Firefox is so popular, my hope is this will be worth doing.

Workaround:

Turns out that Mozilla HTML rendering engine has a bug in how it renders HTML as described in the inserted post below.  Confluence has issues rendering this html.

I also found a fix.  The same program has implemented ability to fix the nested lists.  I can copy the HTML into this program, run its "Clean HTML" program and then paste into Confluence and it renders correctly.   Unfortunately a bit of effort just to paste something into Confluence but at least I know how to deal with it now.

Once you have pasted into Confluence, there does not seem to be a way to fix this from the HTML that Confluence has.  It modifies it enough that the program can no longer fix the lists.

BlueGriffon is available here: http://bluegriffon.org/pages/Download
-------

Post from bluegriffon@googlegroups.com:

On 2/2/11 12:25 PM, "Keith S." wrote:

On Jan 26, 10:05 pm, Daniel Glazman  wrote:
Le 26/01/11 23:47, Keith S. a crit :

> Hi there,

> I just downloaded BlueGriffon today (0.8.1 nightly), as I'm looking
> for a good, simple WYSIWIG editor to recommend to the people in my
> office who INSIST on using MS Word, despite my pleas not to.

> One thing I noticed -- which is an issue for me, because I have tools
> that depend on this -- is that you are not generating your nested
> lists correctly. The nested list is appearing AFTER the list item,
> instead of INSIDE the previous list item.

Yes. That's an old bug (really old) in the Netscape/Mozilla editor.
I am working on it. In the meantime there's an option fixing the
lists in Tools > Markup Cleaner.

</Daniel>

Ah, I didn't realize that was your base. Okay, that makes sense then.
(Everybody has this bug -- even otherwise-pristine-markup-generator
Open Office.)

Thanks for the tip on the option - very useful!
